reviewText: WHERE'S CHARLEY?  Yes, where?  In some vault gathering dust?  Ray Bolger was an incomparably unique dancer.  Unlike Fred Astaire or Gene Kelly who danced straight, Bolger danced funny.  So much harder to do!  I only saw Where's Charley? once; I need to see it many more times.  Where's the DVD?THE BEGGAR'S OPERA.  And where is this one hiding?  What could be better than Laurence Olivier singing and hamming it up as Mack the Knife?  This is the only movie I know that spoofs the operatic form, blowing it to pieces by scenes such as Olivier singing operatically while riding a horse.  The movie takes the title "Beggar's Opera" seriously, that is, hilariously.  Even the magnificent stage production "The Threepenny Opera" doesn't quite do That!Come on, you sleepy keepers of the cinematic vault.  Skip the next ten forgettable titles you're about to issue in DVD, and print the above two masterpieces.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've seen this movie several times, and I've always thought it was very well done. Considering how many lesser known movies are finally reaching home video it is so disappointing this is taking so long.
summary: Please release this to DVD & Blu ray!
Title: N/A

reviewText: We did this as our high school play my senior year (1970) & I have never had so much fun. I fell in love with the songs & the story. I only saw the movie once on late late night TV & Ray Bolger was terrific. I would love to be able to show it to my daughter as she shares my love for musicals. Please some one, find "Charley" so we can all fall in love with Amy again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Frank Loesser's widow, Jo Sullivan, reportedly has a dislike for the film version of her husband's first big Broadway hit, and therefore will not allow a DVD version to be released.It is sad that Ms. Sullivan cannot get past her own prejudices in order to offer her husband's fans the gift of seeing this great cinematic classic again.  Nor can I imagine Mr. Loesser would share her sentiments.  His music was meant to be enjoyed forever. Let's hope that Ms. Sullivan gets over her selfishness soon and allows a DVD release so that we may all continue to celebrate the life and music of Frank Loesser.
summary: Loesser's widow opposed to DVD release
Title: N/A

reviewText: Actually, no one has seen the DVD yet, but I saw this film a few times in theatres in the late fifties, then a few more times on late night TV, so I feel qualified to critique it----the number Mr.Bolger performs, "Once in Love with Amy" is worth the whole price of admission to this movie---the story, (from the play "Charley's Aunt") is very humorous and the period locales, London, are pleasant to watch.  The girl who played Amy, Allyn McLerie,  was in the Doris Day film, "Calamity Jane", and is pretty to watch.  A pity she didn't make more films.  All in all, an excellent film and I anxiously await the DVD,with the hopes of good restoration and perhaps a few notes in the asides.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I loved this movie and in the intervening... what? half century???...since I saw it, I've never stopped wanting to see it again. I bought the non-musical version of Charley's Aunt, with Jack Benny (omigod, I loved Benny, but why in the name of all that's holy did they let him try a British accent?????). Other than that, it was fun and funny, but nowhere near as hilarious as Where's Charley with Ray Bolger.  My fingers are crossed that they release it on DVD while I'm still alive to see it!
summary: A DVD would be a dream come true
Title: N/A
